questions.text: A 58-year-old male, who had a myocardial infarction one week ago, presents to the emergency department holding a clenched fist over his chest. Which biochemical marker would be most useful in confirming reinfarction in this patient?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Preferred biochemical markers due to their sensitivity and specificity.
  • ↳ Preferred biochemical markers
  • ↳ Criteria for ACS: Requires rise and/or fall in biomarker values, with at least one value above the 99th percentile upper reference limit.
  • ↳ Criteria for ACS:
  • ↳ Troponin T (cTnT) and Troponin I (cTnI ) increase significantly after STEMI.
  • ↳ Troponin T (cTnT)
  • ↳ Troponin I (cTnI
  • ↳ Can detect concentrations <1 ng/L in non-ischemic conditions.
  • ↳ <1 ng/L
  • ↳ Troponin levels: Increase within 3-6 hours. Peak at around 36 hours. Remains elevated for 7-10 days after STEMI.
  • ↳ Troponin levels:
  • ↳ Increase within 3-6 hours. Peak at around 36 hours. Remains elevated for 7-10 days after STEMI.
  • ↳ Increase within 3-6 hours.
  • ↳ Peak at around 36 hours.
  • ↳ Remains elevated for 7-10 days after STEMI.
  • ↳ 7-10 days
  • ↳ Troponin should be measured at presentation and repeated at 1-3 hours (high-sensitivity assays) or 3-6 hours (conventional assays).
  • ↳ Further troponin tests are advised beyond 3-6 hours if AMI remains a possibility or there is diagnostic uncertainty.

  • ↳ CK-MB: (Option B)
  • ↳ CK rises within 4-8 hours. Peaks by 24 hours. Returns to normal within 48-72 hours. CK lacks specificity for STEMI since it can be elevated in skeletal muscle disease, trauma, or injections. CK-MB isoenzyme is more specific for the heart CK-MB elevated: Cardiac surgery Myocarditis Electrical cardioversion CK-MB/CK ratio >2.5 suggests a myocardial source, though it's not diagnostic. Causes of elevated Serum Troponin other AMI

Cardiorespiratory Causes

Non-Cardiorespiratory Causes

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman comes at night with chest pain that started earlier that evening and has progressively worsened. She describes the pain as a burning sensation accompanied by a sour taste in her mouth, which began shortly after dinner. She has had similar experiences previously, but not as severe as now. Initial laboratory tests and an ECG show normal results. What is the most likely cause of this patient's chest pain?
questions.explanation:
Cardiopulmonary causes

Non-cardiopulmonary causes

Cardiac causes:

  • Myocardial ischemia
  • Pericarditis

Gastrointestinal causes:

  • Esophageal reflux
  • Esophageal spasm
  • Peptic ulcer
  • Gallbladder disease

Vascular causes:

  • Acute aortic syndrome
  • Pulmonary embolism
  • Pulmonary hypertension

Neuromuscular causes:

  • Costochondritis
  • Cervical disc disease
  • Trauma or strain
  • Herpes zoster

Pulmonary causes:

  • Pneumonia or pleuritis
  • Spontaneous pneumothorax

Psychological causes:

  • Emotional and psychiatric conditions

History

Highly suspicious

Moderately suspicious

Slightly suspicious

2

1

0

ECG

Significant ST depression

Nonspecific abnormality

Normal

2

1

0

Age

≥65 years

45 to <65 years

<45 years

2

1

0

Risk factors

≥3 risk factors

1-2 risk factors

None

2

1

0

TOTAL

Low risk: 0-3

Not low risk: ≥4

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents with acute onset of severe dyspnea and shock 5 days after a STEMI. On examination, a loud pansystolic murmur is heard at the apex. Echocardiography reveals valvular dysfunction. What is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.explanation:
Hemodynamic Failure
  • Pump Failure: Leading cause of in-hospital death after STEMI; severity correlates with infarct size.
  • Signs: Pulmonary rales, S3/S4 gallop sounds, pulmonary congestion on chest x-ray. Elevated LV filling and pulmonary artery pressures due to diastolic/systolic dysfunction.

Killip Classification:

  • Class I: No pulmonary/venous congestion.
  • Class II: Moderate heart failure (rales, S3 gallop, right-sided heart failure).
  • Class III: Severe heart failure with pulmonary edema.
  • Class IV: Cardiogenic shock with systolic BP <90 mmHg, peripheral vasoconstriction.

Management:

  • Use of balloon catheters and intra-arterial pressure monitoring.
  • Diuresis for elevated LV pressure, volume expansion for lower LV pressure.

Ventricular Aneurysm (Option C)

Occurs in ~10% of MI patients, especially with persistent vessel occlusion.

  • Clinical Signs: Paradoxical chest wall impulse, persistent ST elevation on ECG, and abnormal cardiac silhouette on chest X-ray.
  • Diagnosis: Confirmed by echocardiography.
  • Complications: Includes heart failure, ventricular arrhythmias, mural thrombus, and systemic embolism.

Rupture

Papillary Muscle Rupture (Option B)

  • Presents with acute pulmonary edema and shock due to sudden severe mitral regurgitation.
  • Often associated with a pansystolic murmur and 3rd heart sound.
  • Confirmed with echocardiography; emergency valve replacement may be required.
 

Ventricular Septum Rupture (Option A)

  • Characterized by sudden hemodynamic deterioration and a loud pansystolic murmur radiating to the right sternal border.
  • Causes left-to-right shunting through a ventricular septal defect, often leading to acute right heart failure.
  • Confirmed by Doppler echocardiography and right heart catheterization.
  • Emergency surgical repair is essential.
 

Ventricular Rupture (Option D)

  • Leads to cardiac tamponade and is usually fatal.
  • incomplete ruptures may allow for emergency surgical repair.

Embolism
  • Thrombus can form on infarcted myocardium, leading to systemic embolism, which may cause stroke or ischemic limb.
  • Venous thrombosis and pulmonary embolism are less common with prophylactic anticoagulants and early mobilization.

Ventricular Remodelling
  • Occurs after a transmural MI, with thinning and stretching of the infarcted area leading to ventricular dilatation and hypertrophy.
  • Progressive dilatation increases wall stress, reducing efficiency and potentially causing heart failure.
  • ACE inhibitors and mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists can reduce late ventricular remodeling and help prevent heart failure.

Death

  • Cause of death after MI
  • According to time after MI
    • 1st hour- Ventricular Fibrillation /Ventricular Tachycardia
    • 1st day- Cardiogenic shock
    • 3rd day- Cardiac rupture

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presents 6 weeks after experiencing an ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). He reports malaise, fever, and chest discomfort that worsens with deep breathing. On examination, a pericardial friction rub is heard. Laboratory tests reveal leukocytosis and an elevated ESR. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Arrhythmias

Arrhythmias are common soon after symptom onset, due to factors like autonomic imbalance and ischemia.

  • Ventricular Premature Beats (VPBs): Beta-blockers are recommended to reduce ectopic activity and prevent ventricular fibrillation.
  • Ventricular Tachycardia (VT) & Fibrillation (VF):
  • VT and VF can occur within the first 24 hours without warning.
  • Prophylactic lidocaine is no longer recommended as it does not reduce mortality and may increase the risk of bradycardia and asystole.
  • Amiodarone is the preferred treatment for sustained VT, with electroversion for severe cases.
  • VT or VF refractory to electroshock may respond to epinephrine or amiodarone.
  • Accelerated Idioventricular Rhythm (AIVR):
  • AIVR, also known as "slow ventricular tachycardia," is a ventricular rhythm with a rate of 60–100 beats per minute.
  • It commonly occurs transiently during fibrinolytic therapy, especially at the time of reperfusion.
  • Benign and not indicative of more serious arrhythmias.
  • Rarely progresses to classic VT.
  • Requires no treatment with careful monitoring.
  • Torsades de pointes may be due to electrolyte imbalances or drug toxicity. Investigate and address underlying causes in these cases.
  • Sinus tachycardia is the most common, often secondary to other conditions (e.g., fever, heart failure). Treat underlying causes first.
  • Sinus Bradycardia: Treated with atropine if it causes hemodynamic compromise. Persistent bradycardia may require pacing.

Dressler Syndrome
  • It is also known as post-myocardial infarction syndrome, it typically occurs 1 to 8 weeks after MI.
  • Symptoms: Patients may experience malaise, fever, pericardial discomfort, leukocytosis, elevated ESR, and pericardial effusion.
  • Pathology: Fibrinous pericarditis with polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs) is often found at autopsy.
  • Cause: Likely involves an immunopathologic process.
  • Treatment:
  • Aspirin (650 mg every 4 hours) is the main treatment. (Option B)
  • Glucocorticosteroids and NSAIDs should be avoided within 4 weeks of STEMI due to risks of impaired infarct healing, ventricular rupture. (Option A & C)

questions.text: A 72-year-old female with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with severe chest pain for 1 hour. Her ECG shows ST-elevation indicating a STEMI. She has a blood pressure of 180/110 mmHg and a history of active peptic ulcer disease. What is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?

A 60-year-old male with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with chest pain lasting 45 minutes. His ECG confirms a STEMI, and he is stable with a blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg. Which of the following statements about his acute myocardial infarction management is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Beta blockers should be avoided in all patients with acute MI.

options.label: B
options.text: ACE inhibitors are contraindicated due to his blood pressure.

options.label: C
options.text: LMWH provides more reliable anticoagulation than UFH.

options.label: D
options.text: Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors are not useful in acute MI.

questions.correct_answer: C. LMWH provides more reliable anticoagulation than UFH.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with severe chest pain lasting 30 minutes. His ECG is taken and shown below. He has no known allergies, his blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg, and his oxygen saturation is 98%. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer morphine 2-4 mg IV for pain relief

options.label: B
options.text: Administer nifedipine 20 mg to relieve chest pain

options.label: C
options.text: Administer clopidogrel (300 mg loading dose) for platelet inhibition

options.label: D
options.text: Administer sublingual nitroglycerin (0.4 mg) to reduce myocardial oxygen demand

questions.correct_answer: B. Administer nifedipine 20 mg to relieve chest pain

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with chest pain and is suspected of having an acute myocardial infarction (MI). Which of the following imaging techniques would provide the most accurate diagnosis of the MI?
A 58-year-old male presents with chest pain, and an ECG reveals the following changes. Based on these findings, which coronary artery is most likely affected?
questions.explanation:
Infarct Location

Affected Coronary Artery

Leads

Lateral Wall MI

Left Circumflex Artery (LCx) (Option A)

V5, V6, I, aVL

Septal Wall MI

Septal Branch of Left Anterior Descending Artery (LAD)

V1, V2

Anterior Wall MI

Left Anterior Descending Artery (LAD)

V1-V4, I, aVL

Extensive Anterior Wall MI

Left Main Coronary Artery (LMCA)

V1-V6, I, aVL

Posterior Wall MI

Posterior Descending Artery (PDA) (Option D)

V1-V4 (ST depression), V7, V8, V9 (ST elevation)

Inferior Wall MI

Right Coronary Artery (RCA) (Option B)

Leads II, III, aVF

NSTEMI (Anterior Wall)

Left Anterior Descending Artery (LAD)

Often subtle changes in V1-V4

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with a history of coronary artery disease undergoes angiography, which reveals a thrombus in the right coronary artery (RCA). Based on this finding, which area of the heart is most likely to be affected by an infarct?
questions.explanation:
Coronary Artery Affected

Location of Infarct

Left Coronary Artery (LCA)
  • Anterior Wall MI (most common) (Option A ruled out)
  • Extensive Anterior Wall MI

Left Circumflex Artery (LCX)

Lateral Wall MI (Option B ruled out)

Left Anterior Descending (LAD)
  • Anterior Wall MI
  • Septal MI (Option D ruled out)

Right Coronary Artery (RCA)

Inferior Wall MI

Posterior Descending Artery (PDA)
  • Inferior Wall MI
  • Posterior Wall MI

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with acute chest pain radiating to his left arm. An ECG is performed, but upon review, the physician notices that Lead II has been incorrectly connected. To ensure accurate representation of the heart's electrical activity, the physician asks you to correct the lead placement. Which of the following connections should be made to achieve the correct placement for Lead II on the ECG?
questions.correct_answer: D. Right arm (−) to Left leg (+)

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents to the emergency department with chest pain radiating to his left shoulder, which did not relieve with rest. An ECG is conducted. What is the earliest sign of myocardial infarction that is most likely to be seen on the ECG?

A 60-year-old male presents with a sudden onset of severe chest pain that radiates to his left arm. This pain started about 30 minutes ago while he was at rest. His medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. An ECG has been performed and cardiac biomarkers are significantly elevated. What is the most likely cause of his presentation?

A 72-year-old man present with chest pain and shortness of breath. He has a history of coronary artery disease and underwent a percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) two days ago. An ECG shows ST-segment depression, and initial cTn values are found to be normal. Later, the cTn levels rise to five times the 99th percentile of the upper limit. What is the diagnosis here?
questions.explanation:

  • ↳ Type 1 MI (Option A) It is defined when there is a rise and/or fall of cardiac troponin (cTn) with at least one value above the 99th percentile of the upper limit. With at least one of the following: Symptoms of acute myocardial injury . New ischemic ECG changes. Development of pathological Q waves . Imaging evidence of new loss of viable myocardium or new regional wall motion abnormality consistent with ischemia. Identification of a coronary thrombus by angiography, intracoronary imaging, or autopsy.

  • ↳ Requires a tenfold increase in cTn values if initial values are normal.
  • ↳ tenfold increase in cTn values
  • ↳ If initial cTn values are above the 99th percentile URL, a 20% rise is needed, with final values exceeding ten times the 99th percentile.

Universal definition of MI

  • Myocardial injury is when there is evidence of elevated cardiac troponin (cTn) levels with at least one value above the 99th percentile upper reference limit (URL).
  • Myocardial injury can be considered acute if the cTn values rise and/or fall.

Types of MI

Type 1 MI (Option A)
  • It is defined when there is a rise and/or fall of cardiac troponin (cTn) with at least one value above the 99th percentile of the upper limit.
  • With at least one of the following:
    • Symptoms of acute myocardial injury.
    • New ischemic ECG changes.
    • Development of pathological Q waves.
    • Imaging evidence of new loss of viable myocardium or new regional wall motion abnormality consistent with ischemia.
    • Identification of a coronary thrombus by angiography, intracoronary imaging, or autopsy.

Type 2 MI (Option B)
  • This does not include the identification of coronary thrombus.
  • Develops secondary to another illness or process.
  • Possible mechanisms include:
    • Fixed coronary atherosclerosis
    • Coronary spasm
    • Coronary embolism
    • Coronary artery dissection
    • Sustained tachyarrhythmia
    • Severe bradyarrhythmia
    • Severe hypertension
    • Respiratory failure
    • Shock
    • Severe anemia or hypotension

Type 3 MI
  • Very rare, constituting 3–4% of all MIs.
  • Defined as death from probable cardiac causes.
  • Distinction from non-cardiac causes of sudden death is important.
  • Autopsy findings of fresh or recent thrombus in the infarct-related artery confirm Type 1 MI instead of Type 3 MI.

Type 4a MI related to percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI)
  • Requires a fivefold increase in cTn values if initial values are normal.
  • If initial cTn values are above the 99th percentile URL, a 20% rise is needed, with final values exceeding five times the 99th percentile.

Type 4b MI
  • This is associated with a stent thrombosis.

Type 4c MI
  • Associated with focal or diffuse restenosis after PCI.
  • Defined by a rise and/or fall of cTn values above the 99th percentile URL.
  • Diagnosis aligns with the criteria for Type 1 MI.

Type 5 MI related to coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) (Option C)
  • Requires a tenfold increase in cTn values if initial values are normal.
  • If initial cTn values are above the 99th percentile URL, a 20% rise is needed, with final values exceeding ten times the 99th percentile.

questions.text: Which of the following vessels is at the greatest risk of atherosclerosis, arranged from highest to lowest?

options.label: A
options.text: Popliteal arteries > Coronary arteries > Circle of Willis > Abdominal aorta

options.label: B
options.text: Coronary arteries > Abdominal aorta > Circle of Willis > Popliteal arteries

options.label: C
options.text: Abdominal aorta > Coronary arteries > Popliteal arteries > Circle of Willis

options.label: D
options.text: Coronary arteries > Circle of Willis > Abdominal aorta > Popliteal arteries

questions.correct_answer: C. Abdominal aorta > Coronary arteries > Popliteal arteries > Circle of Willis

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with chest pain similar to episodes he experienced in the past. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The ECG shows ST-segment depression <0.5mm, and his cardiac troponin levels are elevated. Using the TIMI risk scoring system, what is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient's condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Discharge with a referral for outpatient stress testing

options.label: C
options.text: Initiate high-dose atorvastatin and schedule for follow-up in one month

options.label: D
options.text: Administer sublingual nitroglycerin and start intravenous beta-blockers

questions.correct_answer: D. Administer sublingual nitroglycerin and start intravenous beta-blockers
questions.explanation:
Risk factors
  • Age ≥65 years
  • Known coronary artery disease
  • ST deviation >0.5mm on presenting ECG
  • Raised cardiac markers
  • ≥2 original episodes in the prior 24 hours
  • Prior angina
  • ≥3 CAD risk factors

Number of risk factors

Incidence of adverse cardiac events (%)

0/1

5

2

8

3

13

4

20

5

26

6/7

41

Medical management

Anti-ischemic therapy:

  • Sublingual glyceryl trinitrate/nitroglycerin:
    • DOC for unstable angina
    • For ischemic discomfort
  • IV beta-blockers (Atenolol, Metoprolol):
    • They reduce the oxygen demand of the myocardium
    • They relieve pain, reduce arrhythmias, and reduce short-term mortality
  • Verapamil and diltiazem:
    • Given if symptoms are not relieved by full dose beta blockers and nitrates
    • They decrease the heart rate
  • IV morphine sulfate or diamorphine:
    • For analgesia
  • Antiemetics like metoclopramide (For symptomatic relief)
  • Nifedipine or amlodipine (If chest discomfort persists)
  • Atorvastatin and other HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors: Reduces occurrence of MI and recurrences of acute coronary syndrome
  • Ezetimibe or alirocumab, evolocumab:
    • Given if unresponsive to full dose statins
    • They reduce LDL cholesterol and prevent further cardiovascular events

Antithrombotic therapy:

  • Antiplatelet drugs:
    • Cyclooxygenase inhibitor: aspirin
    • Platelet P2Y12 receptor inhibitor: clopidogrel

Anticoagulants:

  • Unfractionated heparin.
  • Low molecular heparin: enoxaparin.
  • Direct thrombin inhibitor: bivalirudin.
  • Synthetic factor Xa inhibitor: fondaparinux.

Invasive management
  • Done if the medical management fails and symptoms do not improve. (Option A)
  • Coronary arteriography must be done within 48 hours of presentation.
  • Coronary revascularization includes PCI (percutaneous coronary intervention) or coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).

NSTE-ACS

NSTEMI

STEMI
  • Non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome
  • Include both NSTEMI and unstable angina

Non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction

ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction

ST-segment elevation absent

ST-segment depression or T-wave inversions

Significant ST-segment elevation

Normal troponin levels (in unstable angina) or elevated (in NSTEMI)

Elevated

Elevated

Myocardial necrosis is present (NSTEMI) / absent (unstable angina)

Myocardial necrosis is present

Myocardial necrosis is present

High risk for myocardial infarction

Serious ischemia, further evaluation needed

Urgent reperfusion therapy required

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes presents to your office with chest discomfort at rest, jaw pain, and nausea. On examination, she appears anxious, with cool, pale skin. The symptoms occurred suddenly 2 hours ago and are getting worse. She has a 20-pack-year smoking history. An ECG shows multiple T wave inversions and ST depressions in contiguous leads, and lab reports show raised Trop-I. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old male presents with chest pain. ECG is given below. Considering this presentation, which of the following conditions could be responsible for the observed ST elevations? Hyperkalemia Variant Angina Digoxin (Therapeutic doses) Left Ventricular Hypertrophy (LVH) Chronic Stable Angina
questions.explanation:
ST Elevation

ST Depression
  • Acute Myocardial Infarction (STEMI)
  • Prinzmetal Angina (Option 2)
  • Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB)
  • Brugada syndrome
  • Left Ventricular Hypertrophy (LVH) (Option 4)
  • Pericarditis
  • Benign early repolarization
  • Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy
  • Aortic Dissection
  • Hyperkalemia (Option 1)
  • Non-ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (NSTEMI)
  • Digoxin (Therapeutic doses) (Option 3 ruled out)
  • Chronic Stable Angina (Option 5 ruled out)
  • Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
  • Hypokalemia

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with episodes of chest pain occurring at rest, particularly during the night. His symptoms are often triggered by emotional stress and are relieved by nitroglycerin. An ECG was performed and is given below. There is no elevation of cardiac markers. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 62-year-old male presents to the emergency department with episodes of chest pain at rest that lasts for about 15 minutes and shortness of breath. The pain is central and radiates to the left arm and jaw. His medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Investigations show normal enzyme levels. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this patient's condition?

A 65-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 30-minute episode of chest discomfort that occurred while she was watching television. She describes the pain as a tightness in his chest, radiating to her left arm. She has a history of diabetes and high cholesterol. An ECG reveals inverted T-waves. Which of the following investigations is considered the most crucial next step in evaluating her condition?
questions.explanation:
Investigations

  • ECG is the first and must investigation in this case, and it shows:
    • Hyperacute T-waves
    • Flat T-waves
    • Inverted T-waves (25% cases)
    • ST depression (25% cases)
    • Normal ST wave (50%)
    • Most commonly, sinus rhythm is seen in unstable angina
  • Blood investigations:
  • CBC, platelet count, metabolic profile
  • Troponin test for infarction (normal or slightly elevated)
  • Coagulation studies
  • Chest X-ray to rule out other conditions.
  • Cardiac stress tests: (Option C)
  • Walking treadmill stress test
  • Stress echocardiogram
  • Myocardial perfusion imaging (Option D)
  • Cardiac CT/MRI
  • Cardiac catheterization (Gold standard) (Option B)

questions.text: What is the revascularization procedure of choice for triple vessel disease and left main coronary artery disease, respectively?

options.label: D
options.text: PCI with stenting; PCI with stenting

questions.explanation:
Condition

Preferred Treatment
  • Single or two-vessel disease (non-proximal LAD, non-left main)
  • High surgical risk (comorbidities)
  • Contraindication to surgery
  • Elderly patients (>80 years or frailty)

PCI (Percutaneous Coronary Intervention)
  • Multivessel disease
  • Proximal LAD involvement
  • Left main coronary artery involvement
  • In-stent restenosis (with DES in major arteries)

CABG (Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting)

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with chronic stable angina presents with worsening chest pain during routine activities. His current medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, metoprolol, and atorvastatin, but his symptoms persist. ECG shows ST-segment depression in V5-V6, and coronary angiography reveals 80% stenosis of the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. What is the most appropriate intervention?

options.label: C
options.text: Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with drug-eluting stent (DES)

options.label: D
options.text: Refer for coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG)

questions.correct_answer: C. Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with drug-eluting stent (DES)
questions.explanation:
Medication Class

Function/Mechanism

Indications

Side Effects/

Contraindication

Nitrates

Sublingual nitroglycerin (0.4 or 0.6 mg)

Long-acting forms (oral, transdermal)
  • Systemic venodilation
  • Reduces LV end-diastolic volume and pressure
  • Releases nitric oxide (NO) to relax vascular smooth muscle
  • Angina relief
  • Preemptive use before activities
  • Improves exercise tolerance
  • Tolerance development
  • Headaches, dizziness

Beta-Blocker (Option A)
  • Reduces heart rate, arterial pressure, and myocardial contractility
  • Improves survival post-MI
  • Angina relief
  • Reduces mortality and reinfarction rates
  • Asthma
  • AV conduction disturbances
  • Severe bradycardia

Calcium Channel Blockers
  • Coronary vasodilators
  • Reduces myocardial oxygen demand and arterial pressure
  • Dihydropyridines (e.g., amlodipine) and non-dihydropyridines (e.g., verapamil)
  • Angina treatment when beta blockers are ineffective
  • Variant angina
  • Bradyarrhythmias
  • May aggravate LV failure

Antiplatelet Drugs
  • Aspirin: inhibits platelet activation
  • Clopidogrel 75mg: blocks platelet aggregation
  • Reduces coronary events in high-risk populations
  • Stent placement
  • Risk of bleeding
  • Gastrointestinal issues, allergies

Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI) (Option C)

PCI involves balloon dilatation and stenting for symptomatic IHD with suitable stenoses in epicardial coronary arteries.

  • Indications:
    • Symptom-limiting angina despite optimal medical therapy.
    • Evidence of ischemia during stress tests.
  • Post-PCI Management:
    • Aspirin is administered indefinitely, and P2Y12 antagonists for 1-3 months.
    • Current-generation drug-eluting stents reduce restenosis but require prolonged dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT).

Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG) (Option D)

Involves bypassing obstructive lesions using internal mammary arteries, radial arteries, or saphenous veins.

  • Indications:
    • Safe with low mortality in patients without serious comorbidities and normal LV function.
    • Effective for patients with left main coronary artery stenosis, multivessel disease, or impaired LV function.
  • Outcomes:
    • Angina relief in ~90% of patients after complete revascularization.
    • Long-term survival benefits in specific populations, particularly those with diabetes or impaired LV function.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of CAD presents with recurrent syncope. He has no obvious structural heart disease on echocardiography. Considering his intermediate to high risk for CAD, which imaging modality would be most appropriate for further evaluation?
questions.correct_answer: A. Myocardial Perfusion Imaging with Thallium-201 (Tl-201)
questions.explanation:
Myocardial perfusion imaging

Done with Technetium-99m (Tc-99m) or Thallium-201 (Tl-201).

Indications:

  • CAD Detection
  • Heart Failure Assessment
  • Ventricular Tachycardia: Investigating high-risk patients for CAD.
  • Syncope Evaluation: Assessing syncope in those at intermediate to high risk for CAD.
  • Indeterminate Previous Results
  • Angina Symptoms
  • Post-Revascularization Assessment: Risk assessment for patients with ischemic symptoms, incomplete revascularization in asymptomatic individuals, or those more than 5 years post-CABG.
  • Myocardial Viability: Determining revascularization candidacy based on myocardial viability.

Stress Echocardiography (Option B ruled out)
  • Used in patients who cannot exercise or have resting ECG abnormalities, preferred for evaluating LV function and ischemia.
  • Image quality can be affected by obesity and COPD.
  • Technician-dependent.

Positron Emission Tomography (PET) (Option D ruled out)

Functionality assesses myocardial viability through glucose metabolism.

Advantages:

  • High sensitivity and contrast resolution for detecting ischemia.
  • High predictive value for future cardiac events.
  • Enhanced detection of multi-vessel disease and active atherosclerotic plaques with new radiotracers.
  • Potential to avoid unnecessary interventions, despite high costs.

Multigated Acquisition (MUGA) Scanning (Option C ruled out)

Indications:

  • Cardiac Function in Chemotherapy: Evaluates cardiac function in patients receiving potentially cardiotoxic chemotherapy.
  • Anatomical Assessment: Assesses the orientation of the heart and great vessels in the chest.
  • Ischemic Disease Detection: Identifies undiagnosed ischemic disease in patients with hypodynamic wall motion without prior myocardial infarction.
  • Heart Failure Evaluation: Determines systolic or diastolic dysfunction in undiagnosed congestive heart failure by analyzing ventricular filling and contraction.
  • Valvular Function and COPD: Evaluates valve motion and associated ventricular function, cardiac function in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and checks for intracardiac shunts

Hibernating myocardium

Stunned myocardium
  • Ischemic myocardium where cells remain viable but have chronically depressed contraction due to reduced blood supply from a narrowed artery.
  • Viable, chronically reduced contraction
  • Viable myocardium that shows prolonged dysfunction after blood flow has been restored (reperfusion).
  • Viable, post-ischemic dysfunction

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with chronic stable angina that has progressively worsened despite optimal medical therapy. He underwent myocardial stress testing, which indicated ischemia. What is the next best step in diagnosing the extent of his coronary artery disease?
questions.explanation:
Investigation

Indications

Limitations

Exercise Treadmill Test

Initial test for intermediate-risk patients without resting ECG abnormalities; used for risk stratification and diagnosis of CAD.

Non-diagnostic in patients with LBBB, LVH, paced rhythm, or digoxin use.

Stress Echocardiography (Option A)

Used in patients who cannot exercise or have resting ECG abnormalities; preferred for evaluating LV function and ischemia.

Image quality can be affected by obesity and COPD; technician-dependent.

Myocardial Perfusion Imaging (Option B)

Preferred for patients with prior revascularization, resting ECG abnormalities, or high risk of ischemia.

Expensive; exposes patients to ionizing radiation.

Cardiac Magnetic Resonance Imaging

Indicated for comprehensive assessment of myocardial function, perfusion, structural heart disease, and subendocardial ischemia.

Contraindicated in patients with metallic implants; long acquisition times.

Coronary Computed Tomography Angiography (CCTA) (Option D)

Alternative for patients with inconclusive ETT results or lower risk; also evaluates CABG patency and coronary artery anomalies.

May not detect all critical stenoses; exposes patients to radiation.

Coronary Angiography

Gold standard for definitive diagnosis of CAD in patients with confirmed ischemia or medically refractory angina.

Invasive, high cost,

questions.text: A 60-year-old male undergoes a treadmill ECG stress test and develops 2 mm of horizontal ST-segment depression after 8 minutes of exercise. He reports non-limiting chest pain (angina index = 1). What is his Duke Treadmill Score (DTS) and his risk category?
questions.explanation:
Risk

DTS

Interpretation

Low Risk

≥ 5

No need for further coronary angiography.

Intermediate Risk (Option C)

+4 to –10

May need further tests, such as myocardial perfusion scanning or coronary angiography.

High Risk

< –10

Requires further investigation with coronary angiography.

questions.text: An elderly male with a history of cigarette smoking and hypertension develops chest pain after an evening walk. The pain is relieved after lying down for a few minutes. A treadmill stress test reveals ST-segment depression. What is the most likely cause attributed to this clinical presentation?
Arrange the following structures of an atherosclerotic plaque from the innermost to the outermost layer: Fibrous cap Necrotic core Foam cell layer Media

options.label: A
options.text: Fibrous cap → Foam cell layer→ Necrotic core → Media

options.label: B
options.text: Necrotic core → Media → Foam cell layer → Fibrous cap

options.label: C
options.text: Foam cell layer → Fibrous cap → Media→ Necrotic core

options.label: D
options.text: Foam cell layer → Necrotic core → Fibrous cap → Media

questions.correct_answer: A. Fibrous cap → Foam cell layer→ Necrotic core → Media
questions.explanation:
Endothelium

The innermost arterial lining that regulates blood flow, prevents clot formation, and controls inflammation. Damage to the endothelium due to factors like hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking initiates plaque formation.

Fibrous Cap

Smooth muscle cells from the media migrate to the intima and secrete collagen, forming a protective fibrous cap over the lipid core. Cap stability determines plaque vulnerability.

Foamy Cell Layer

Lipoproteins like LDL accumulate in the subendothelial space after endothelial injury. Macrophages engulf oxidized LDL, becoming foam cells, forming lipid-rich fatty streaks.

Necrotic Core

Foam cells die, releasing lipids and forming a necrotic core, consisting of dead cells and cholesterol crystals. A large necrotic core increases plaque instability.

Media

The smooth muscle-rich middle arterial layer thins and weakens during plaque development as muscle cells move to form the fibrous cap.
